TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen , born in DATE . At present she lives in Liepājā in GPE .
She represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
A.

The applicant lived in GPE until her marriage in GPE ( GPE ) in DATE . Thereafter , together with her husband , a NORP military officer , the applicant briefly lived in the FAC enclave of GPE where she gave birth to her son . In DATE the applicant came to GPE for the first time , when her husband was appointed to a military post in PERSON . She stayed there until DATE , when the family moved to the far north of GPE , where the husband continued his military service . The applicant remained in GPE until DATE , when she came back to PERSON separately from her spouse . Ever since she has been living in GPE alone . Following the formal divorce in DATE , her former husband died in GPE in DATE . Her son and granddaughter live in GPE .

In DATE , under the Status of the Former GPE Citizens Act , the applicant was entered on ORG ( hereinafter referred to as “ the Register ” ) on the basis of her status as “ an ex - GPE citizen ” , a particular category of stateless persons under the NORP law ( see the Relevant domestic law part below ) . The applicant had no specific citizenship at that point .
On DATE the applicant adopted citizenship of GPE . She submits that she did so to be able to leave the territory of GPE and to go abroad on occasional commercial trips with a view to earning money .
On DATE the NORP ORG ( hereinafter referred to as “ the CMA ” ) annulled the applicant 's entry in the ORG and , upon her request , issued her with a temporary residence permit valid until DATE .

On DATE the applicant complained to the ORG , alleging a ORG official had misled her in offering to apply for temporary residence . The applicant stated that she was in fact entitled to the entry on the ORG as a permanent resident of GPE .
On DATE she brought court proceedings , alleging that the decision of the immigration authorities to annul her entry in the ORG was void .
On DATE the applicant denounced her NORP citizenship .
On DATE the ORG rejected the applicant 's claim .
On DATE , on the applicant 's appeal , ORG transmitted the case back to ORG for new examination on the ground of technical defect relating to the composition of the court at first instance .

On DATE the Liepājā City District Court again dismissed the applicant 's action . ORG held that the applicant had been a NORP citizen , and that her entry had been lawfully withdrawn by the ORG from the ORG as she had lost her special status as “ an ex - GPE citizen ” . ORG also noted that the applicant had herself filed an application for a temporary residence permit , which had been granted .

On DATE , on the applicant 's appeal , ORG confirmed the decision of ORG . The appellate court held that , having obtained NORP citizenship , the applicant became subject of GPE , and that her entry could not remain in the ORG .
The applicant appealed to ORG .
She also presented her problems to various parliamentary , executive and non - governmental institutions , but without success .

As the applicant failed to extend her temporary residence permit following its expiry on DATE , she was presented with an expulsion order on DATE . She refused to sign the deportation order pending her cassation appeal .
On DATE ORG dismissed the cassation appeal , finding that the lower courts had properly decided the case .
By a letter of DATE ORG informed the applicant that her stay in GPE was illegal .
The applicant again approached the immigration authorities , requesting registration as a permanent resident . This was refused . She did not request an extension of her temporary residence permit .
On DATE the applicant introduced a fresh court action , asking to be re - registered .

On DATE ORG rejected the application , finding that the matter had already been decided in the first set of court proceedings which had ended by a final decision of ORG on DATE . The applicant appealed , stating that the action was in fact new . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the appeal .

By a letter of the ORG of DATE the applicant was informed that her continued stay in GPE was illegal , and that she was required to leave the country . She was warned that , otherwise , she would be served with a deportation order .
In a letter to the ORG of CARDINAL DATE the applicant stated that , following the entry into force of the amended LAW on DATE , she became entitled to be registered as a permanent resident of GPE .
On DATE the applicant took up NORP citizenship .

On DATE the ORG Director authorised the immigration authorities to issue the applicant with a permanent residence permit in GPE on the basis of her status as a foreign citizen . By the above decision the deportation order in respect of the applicant was quashed .
On DATE the applicant was issued with a permanent residence permit in GPE .
B. Relevant domestic law
There are CARDINAL categories of permanent residents of GPE :
a ) NORP citizens ;
b ) stateless persons who have the special status of “ ex - GPE citizens ” ;
c ) foreign citizens or other stateless persons who obtain permanent residence permits .

Categories a ) and b ) have the right to be entered on ORG by sole operation of , respectively , LAW and the Status of the Former LAW . The persons in subparagraph c ) can be granted permanent residence permits by decision of a competent authority or by virtue of ORG .
LAW Former LAW DATE provides that only those stateless persons who “ are not or have not been citizens of another State ” can have the special status of an “ ex - GPE citizen ” .

Other foreign citizens or stateless persons must obtain limited ( temporary ) residence permits or visas in order to stay in the country legally in accordance with the Entry and Residence of Foreign Citizens and Stateless Persons Act .
